node.title: Deploy a Ghost blog on GitHub Pages using Gatsby
node.excerpt: If you want to use Ghost as your cms for hosting a blog on GitHub Pages, you need to have a static site generator. We will be using Gatsby to populate the content from our local Ghost installation and deploy it to GitHub Pages.
node.custom_excerpt: If you want to use Ghost as your cms for hosting a blog on GitHub Pages, you need to have a static site generator. We will be using Gatsby to populate the content from our local Ghost installation and deploy it to GitHub Pages.
node.plaintext:
If you want to use Ghost as your cms for hosting a blog on GitHub Pages, you
need to have a static site generator. We will be using Gatsby to populate the
content from our local Ghost installation and deploy it to GitHub Pages.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Prerequisites
In order to follow this tutorial, you should already have Node.js
[https://nodejs.org/en/download/] and Git [https://git-scm.com/downloads] 
installed.

Generate Blog
 1. Install the Ghost-CLI

npm install ghost-cli@latest -g


 2. Make 2 new directories to house your blog

mkdir blog-ghost blog-gatsby


 3. Navigate into the new blog-ghost directory

cd blog-ghost


 4. Install Ghost locally

ghost install local


 5. Set up your freshly installed local instance of Ghost at 
    https://localhost:2368
    (follow the installation instructions)
 6. Navigate into the new blog-gatsby directory

cd ../blog-gatsby


 7. Install the Gatsby-CLI

npm install gatsby-cli -g


 8. Install gatsby-starter-ghost using Gatsby-CLI

gatsby new . https://github.com/TryGhost/gatsby-starter-ghost.git


 9. Before customising test run Gatsby

gatsby develop


 10. Navigate to http://localhost:8000/
 11. Generate Gatsby Integration:
     Inside the Ghost Admin Panel at https://localhost:2368, go to the
     "Integrations" screen and click "+ Add custom integration"
 12. Copy generated "apiUrl" and "contentApiKey" into blog-gatsby/.ghost.json

{
  "development": {
    "apiUrl": "http://localhost:2368",
    "contentApiKey": "<yourContentApiKey>"
  },
  "production": {
    "apiUrl": "http://localhost:2368",
    "contentApiKey": "<yourContentApiKey>"
  }
}


 13. Start Gatsby development

gatsby develop


Publish Blog
 1. Build Blog

gatsby build


 2. View production version at https://localhost:9000

gatsby serve


 3. Integrate Gatsby Blog to GitHub Pages:
    Inside blog-gatsby/

npm install gh-pages


 4. Add GitHub repository name to gatsby-config.js

module.exports = {
  pathPrefix: "/<repository_name>",
}


 5. Add a custom deploy command to package.json

{
  "scripts": {
    "deploy": "gatsby build --prefix-paths && gh-pages -d public"
  }
}


This creates a deploy command that build a static version of your blog and
pushes it to GitHub
6. Add your GitHub repository as the remote origin to your Gatsby Git repository

git remote add origin https://<username>.github.com/<repository_name>


 7. Deploying your Blog:

npm run deploy


You will now be able to see your blog at <username>.github.io<repository_name>.

Additional resources that may be helpful
 * Sourcing from Ghost [https://www.gatsbyjs.org/docs/sourcing-from-ghost/] -
   Gatsby documentation
 * Working With Gatsby [https://ghost.org/docs/api/v3/gatsby/] - Ghost
   documentation
 * Modern publications with Gatsby & Ghost
   [https://www.gatsbyjs.org/blog/2019-01-14-modern-publications-with-gatsby-ghost/] 
   - by John O'Nolan
 * Deploy a Gatsby Site on GitHub Pages for Free
   [https://blog.bitsrc.io/deploy-a-gatsby-site-on-github-pages-for-free-f18853c1b7a9] 
   - by Shaumik Daityari

Conclusion
In this post, you have accomplished the following:

 * Install local Ghost crm blog
 * Install Gatsby blog using Ghost crm data
 * Deploy static Gatsby blog to GitHub Pages

If you have any further questions, please feel free to contact me on Twitter
[https://twitter.com/KasperZutterman]
node.html:
If you want to use Ghost as your cms for hosting a blog on GitHub Pages, you need to have a static site generator. We will be using Gatsby to populate the content from our local Ghost installation and deploy it to GitHub Pages.

Prerequisites

In order to follow this tutorial, you should already have Node.js and Git installed.

Generate Blog

  1. Install the Ghost-CLI
npm install ghost-cli@latest -g
  1. Make 2 new directories to house your blog
mkdir blog-ghost blog-gatsby
  1. Navigate into the new blog-ghost directory
cd blog-ghost
  1. Install Ghost locally
ghost install local
  1. Set up your freshly installed local instance of Ghost at https://localhost:2368
    (follow the installation instructions)
  2. Navigate into the new blog-gatsby directory
cd ../blog-gatsby
  1. Install the Gatsby-CLI
npm install gatsby-cli -g
  1. Install gatsby-starter-ghost using Gatsby-CLI
gatsby new . https://github.com/TryGhost/gatsby-starter-ghost.git
  1. Before customising test run Gatsby
gatsby develop
  1. Navigate to http://localhost:8000/
  2. Generate Gatsby Integration:
    Inside the Ghost Admin Panel at https://localhost:2368, go to the "Integrations" screen and click "+ Add custom integration"
  3. Copy generated "apiUrl" and "contentApiKey" into blog-gatsby/.ghost.json
{
  "development": {
    "apiUrl": "http://localhost:2368",
    "contentApiKey": "<yourContentApiKey>"
  },
  "production": {
    "apiUrl": "http://localhost:2368",
    "contentApiKey": "<yourContentApiKey>"
  }
}
  1. Start Gatsby development
gatsby develop

Publish Blog

  1. Build Blog
gatsby build
  1. View production version at https://localhost:9000
gatsby serve
  1. Integrate Gatsby Blog to GitHub Pages:
    Inside blog-gatsby/
npm install gh-pages
  1. Add GitHub repository name to gatsby-config.js
module.exports = {
  pathPrefix: "/<repository_name>",
}
  1. Add a custom deploy command to package.json
{
  "scripts": {
    "deploy": "gatsby build --prefix-paths && gh-pages -d public"
  }
}

This creates a deploy command that build a static version of your blog and pushes it to GitHub
6. Add your GitHub repository as the remote origin to your Gatsby Git repository

git remote add origin https://<username>.github.com/<repository_name>
  1. Deploying your Blog:
npm run deploy

You will now be able to see your blog at <username>.github.io<repository_name>.

Additional resources that may be helpful

  • Sourcing from Ghost - Gatsby documentation
  • Working With Gatsby - Ghost documentation
  • Modern publications with Gatsby & Ghost - by John O'Nolan
  • Deploy a Gatsby Site on GitHub Pages for Free - by Shaumik Daityari

Conclusion

In this post, you have accomplished the following:

  • Install local Ghost crm blog
  • Install Gatsby blog using Ghost crm data
  • Deploy static Gatsby blog to GitHub Pages

If you have any further questions, please feel free to contact me on Twitter

node.title: Welcome to my blog!
node.excerpt:
Hello world!
I'm Kasper Zutterman, a 20 year old Information Engineering Technology student at Ghent University. I am born an raised in Belgium and enjoy practicing track & field in my spare time.
node.custom_excerpt:
Hello world!
I'm Kasper Zutterman, a 20 year old Information Engineering Technology student at Ghent University. I am born an raised in Belgium and enjoy practicing track & field in my spare time.
node.plaintext:
Hello world!
I'm Kasper Zutterman, a 20 year old Information Engineering Technology student
at Ghent University. I am born an raised in Belgium and enjoy practicing track &
field in my spare time. 

Ok, let’s move on to what this blog is about. Since my other passion is coding,
this will be a technology and programming related blog. I want to share my
experience, helpful guides and fascinating projects.

Glad you came by.  I wanted to welcome you and let you know I appreciate you
spending time here at my blog very much.

Another thing I will always appreciate is your feedback to the blog.  If you
have any comments or suggestions I welcome them and would love to hear them. So
please feel free to contact me via social media!

If you want to know more about me just click here
[https://kasperzutterman.github.io/], and always feel free to leave any comment,
question or feedback.

Hope you enjoy it :)

Cheers,

Kasper
node.html:
Hello world!

I'm Kasper Zutterman, a 20 year old Information Engineering Technology student at Ghent University. I am born an raised in Belgium and enjoy practicing track & field in my spare time.

Ok, let’s move on to what this blog is about. Since my other passion is coding, this will be a technology and programming related blog. I want to share my experience, helpful guides and fascinating projects.

Glad you came by.  I wanted to welcome you and let you know I appreciate you spending time here at my blog very much.

Another thing I will always appreciate is your feedback to the blog.  If you have any comments or suggestions I welcome them and would love to hear them. So please feel free to contact me via social media!

If you want to know more about me just click here, and always feel free to leave any comment, question or feedback.

Hope you enjoy it :)

Cheers,

Kasper
